block.p: Lawmakers Seek to Punish U.N. for Snubbing U.S. Bush administration and Congressional officials expressed anger at the United States' loss of a seat on the United Nations Human Rights Commission, and influential Republicans and Democrats in the House reached an accord that could hold back $244 million in United Nations dues if the seat was not restored. American officials were further angered that the United States was also voted off the International Narcotics Control Board.

Spy Plane Won't Fly Home Chinese officials said they would not permit the damaged American spy plane to fly home from Hainan island, where it landed after colliding with a Chinese fighter on April 1. American experts had examined the plane and expressed hope that it could be repaired and flown out. China did not rule out another method -- dismantling the plane and sending it home in pieces.

U.S. Military Space Plan Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld unveiled a plan to strengthen the military's space programs, but stopped short of advocating putting weapons in space, an idea that had come under sharp criticism from Congressional Democrats.

Stronger U.S.-Japan Ties Urged Deputy Secretary of State Richard L. Armitage urged Tokyo to develop a partnership with Washington that would more closely resemble the alliance between Britain and the United States.
Blair Sets British Elections Prime Minister Tony Blair said Britons would go to the polls on June 7 in an election that opinion surveys indicate will give him a second term.

Infant Casualty Laid to Rest Thousands of mourners in Gaza buried a 4-month-old Palestinian girl, Iman Hajo, who was killed by Israeli fire on Monday. Her body was wrapped in a white shroud and draped with flowers.

Campaign Overhaul Draws New Opposition in House A group of black and Hispanic Democrats in the House threatened to fight campaign-finance overhaul, saying that it could hurt efforts to mobilize minority voters and that their constituents want changes in the electoral system, not in fund-raising.
Choice to Head Drug Agency President Bush is expected to name Representative Asa Hutchinson, an Arkansas Republican, as head of the D.E.A., officials said.

Federal Appellate Nominations President Bush is to announce his first judicial choices today, 11 candidates for federal appeals courts who include women, members of minorities and staunch conservatives.

Bush Energy Plan The Bush administration will encourage widespread use of agricultural, animal and human waste to produce energy, in an effort to expand environmentally friendly energy supplies along with fossil fuels.

Effort to Counter Terror Threat President Bush acknowledged concern about vulnerability to terrorism, telling Vice President Dick Cheney to lead an effort to study the issue and creating an office to deal with it.
Plea Talks on Spy Suspect Prosecutors and lawyers for Robert P. Hanssen, the F.B.I. agent accused of spying for Moscow, were said to have begun plea bargain talks.
Unusually High Pollen Counts The allergy season in the New York metropolitan region has begun with a vengeance, with pollen counts among the highest ever recorded.

Study on Altering Sexuality A psychiatrist at Columbia University, Dr. Robert Spitzer, is reporting that some ''highly motivated'' gays can become heterosexual. Gay rights groups criticized the findings.

Torricelli Helped Donor Try to Collect Foreign Debt As a congressman in 1995, Senator Robert G. Torricelli intervened to help David Chang try to recover $71 million he said North Korea owed him for grain. Mr. Torricelli, a New Jersey Democrat, has denied helping Mr. Chang, a political donor who says he gave Mr. Torricelli unreported cash and gifts -- accusations now under federal investigation.
Ruling on Witness Reliability New York State's high court said expert testimony challenging the reliability of eyewitnesses could be admitted at trial.
Sharpton Lists Conditions The Rev. Al Sharpton said he would support Fernando Ferrer for mayor only if he pledged to endorse black candidates for Bronx borough president and city comptroller.

Study Affirms Preschool Benefit Poor children who attend intensive preschool classes are more likely to graduate from high school and less likely to be arrested than poor children who have not participated.
Law Dean Becomes President N.Y.U. said John E. Sexton, the dean of its law school, would become the university's next president.
New Show for the Apollo The Apollo Theater is planning a new multimedia revue, ''Harlem Song,'' part of an effort to jump-start the struggling landmark.

Utility Assails Pipeline Owner Southern California Edison accused El Paso of inflating natural gas prices in California by $3.7 billion in the past year by using its control of a major pipeline to curtail the flow of gas.

New Sign of Weaker Economy The productivity of American workers, which rose sharply as new technologies took hold and drove the prosperity of the late 1990's, fell in the first quarter for the first time in six years, declining 0.1 percent.
On the Rise at NBC NBC named Andrew Lack, the president of NBC News, as president and chief operating officer, making him the No. 2 executive and the likely successor to Bob Wright.
Editorials: Worrisome signals on drugs; New Jersey's redistricting; springtime for show biz.
